titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the John D. Mattox Papers

controlnote.p: EAD generated by NCSU Libraries' Collection Guides application using data imported from ArchivesSpace.

maintenanceagency.agencyname: North Carolina State University Libraries, Special Collections Research Center

did.abstract: The John D. Mattox Papers contain photographic prints, negatives, and contact sheets, and papers depicting the personal and professional life of John D. Mattox. Personal portraits and snapshots document the lives of Mattox, his wife Mary, their son Douglas, and their extended family. Also included are photographs of the town of Wendell, North Carolina, where the Mattox family lived. The collection also includes photographs taken while Mattox served in Europe during World War II. Relating to Mattox’s professional career as a photographer at North Carolina State University, there are many images of campus scenes, student and faculty portraits, and campus publications featuring Mattox’s work. Wedding photographs, miscellaneous portraits, unidentified original and copied tintypes and cartes de visite, as well as rolled 35 mm negatives are also included. While the majority of the collection is composed of photographs, there are some papers such as news clippings, correspondence, business cards, awards, brochures, and grade reports which belonged to Mattox.

John Douglas Mattox, Sr. (1911-1987) was a photographer with the Visual Aids Department at North Carolina State University from 1949 to 1974. A native of Wendell, North Carolina, Mattox attended North Carolina State College (later North Carolina State University) in the 1930s and enlisted in the Army in 1941, serving in Europe. He married the former Mary Elizabeth Davis of Columbia, South Carolina, and had a son John Douglas Mattox, Jr., called Doug. Mattox was a talented amateur musician and director of the North Carolina State University R.O.T.C. Glee Club.

corpname.part: North Carolina State University Libraries, Special Collections Research Center

acqinfo.p: Donated by John Douglas Mattox, Jr., December, 1998.

arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into the following series: Personal Photographs; Extended Family Photographs; Wendell, NC, Photographs; World War II Photographs; North Carolina State University Photographs; Wedding Photographs; Miscellaneous Photographs; Unidentified Photographs; Rolled Negatives; and Papers. Within the series, photographs are arranged and labeled as received.

bioghist.p: John Douglas Mattox, Sr. (1911-1987) was a photographer with the Visual Aids Department at North Carolina State University from 1949 to 1974. A native of Wendell, North Carolina, Mattox attended North Carolina State College (later North Carolina State University) in the 1930s and enlisted in the Army in 1941, serving in Europe. He married the former Mary Elizabeth Davis of Columbia, South Carolina, and had a son John Douglas Mattox, Jr., called Doug. Mattox was a talented amateur musician and director of the North Carolina State University R.O.T.C. Glee Club.

prefercite.p: [Identification of item], John D. Mattox Papers, MC 00261, Special Collections Research Center, North Carolina State University Libraries, Raleigh, NC

processinfo.p: Processed by Aaron Cusick, 2010 March; Encoded by Aaron Cusick, 2010 March

scopecontent.p: The John D. Mattox Papers contain photographic prints, negatives, and contact sheets, and papers depicting the personal and professional life of John D. Mattox. Personal portraits and snapshots document the lives of Mattox, his wife Mary, their son Douglas, and their extended family. Also included are photographs of the town of Wendell, North Carolina, where the Mattox family lived. The collection also includes photographs taken while Mattox served in Europe during World War II. Relating to Mattox’s professional career as a photographer at North Carolina State University, there are many images of campus scenes, student and faculty portraits, and campus publications featuring Mattox’s work. Wedding photographs, miscellaneous portraits, unidentified original and copied tintypes and cartes de visite, as well as rolled 35 mm negatives are also included. While the majority of the collection is composed of photographs, there are some papers such as news clippings, correspondence, business cards, awards, brochures, and grade reports which belonged to Mattox.

userestrict.p: The nature of the NCSU Libraries' Special Collections means that copyright or other information about restrictions may be difficult or even impossible to determine despite reasonable efforts. The NCSU Libraries claims only physical ownership of most Special Collections materials.

The materials from our collections are made available for use in research, teaching, and private study, pursuant to U.S. Copyright law. The user must assume full responsibility for any use of the materials, including but not limited to, infringement of copyright and publication rights of reproduced materials. Any materials used for academic research or otherwise should be fully credited with the source.

corpname.part: North Carolina State University--Students--Social life and customs
North Carolina State University--Alumni and alumnae

scopecontent.p: This series contains portraits and snapshots of John Mattox, his wife Mary, and their son Douglas. The earliest photographs, depicting John Mattox’s early life, are from the 1910s and 1920s. However, the majority of photographs are from the 1940s to the 1970s. These photographs document the Mattox family’s home life including birthday parties, holidays, anniversaries, and social events.

scopecontent.p: This series contains portraits and snapshots of John and Mary Mattox’s extended families, the including siblings, parents, aunts and uncles, and other relatives. John Mattox was the son of Jonathan Joseph and Ernestine Bain Mattox of Wendell, North Carolina. His siblings include Jeanette Mattox Laing, Annie Sue Mattox Faison, Vernon Mattox, and Edward Mattox. Family names in this series include Mattox, Davis, Bain, Faison, and Todd. Due to inconsistent labeling, it is possible that some of the photographs in this series depict individuals not actually related to Mattox.

scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs of various locations and events in Mattox’s hometown of Wendell, North Carolina. Buildings include churches, schools, banks, and businesses. School functions like graduations and homecomings and church activities are also included. This series also contains portraits made by Mattox of people who lived in Wendell. Interesting items include a set of glass plate negatives depicting town scenes circa the late 1920s.

scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs and slides of students and faculty, campus scenes, extension services, and the North Carolina State Fair. Several photographs show Mattox taking pictures or in his office in the Visual Aids Department. There are also images of the R.O.T.C. Glee Club, which Mattox directed. Other interesting images include Mattox’s fifty year class reunion in 1983, retirement banquets for Mattox, and campus publications featuring Mattox’s photographs.

scopecontent.p: This series contains various photographs which document Mattox’s service in Europe during World War II. Locations include Holland, Belgium, England, Germany, and France. The photographs portray Mattox alone or with other soldiers or native Europeans. Several items are of the glee club and band, of which Mattox was a member. Other items include postcards and a miniature set of souvenir photographs of Paris.
This series contains news clippings, correspondence, business cards, awards, brochures, grade reports, and other personal papers belonging to Mattox.
This series contains rolled 35 mm negatives, some of which have corresponding prints elsewhere in the collection.
